Tinder, Grindr Parent Company, Match Sues Apple In India For Overcharging In-App Purchases

  • Youtube
  • Telegram
  • Вконтакте

The parent company of popular dating apps like Tinder and Grindr, Match has reportedly filed an antitrust suit against Apple in India, to challenge its levying of the mandatory 30 percent commission.

As seen in a legal filing by Reuters, the company is accusing the Cupertino giant of ‘monopolistic conduct’ that is forcing devs to pay a massive chunk of their earnings in the form of commissions for every in-app purchase made by the user on the Apple platform.

Apple is already engulfed with antitrust suits with the most recent one adding to the two existing cases in India alone. Match however is the first foreign company to make such a suit against Apple in India.

In the previous unreported filing in India, Match has argued that Apple’s strategy blocks innovation and development for app developers which offer digital services by limiting them to the proprietary in-app purchase system alongside the excessive commission.

Match complains that while ride-hailing apps such as Uber and Ola are given the option of alternative payment solutions, what Match is doing in the dating space is no different.

Match said, "Both dating and ridesharing apps share the same fundamental purpose i.e. matching two people online to meet in the real world ... Apple has arbitrarily declared that the two are different."

A similar suit was filed against Apple in the Netherlands, where the iPhone maker was fined 50 million euros as well as an agreement to permit different payment methods on Dutch dating apps.

The Competition Commission of India commenced an investigation in December for allegations made by a local non-profit group regarding Apple’s payment system and how it is hurting competition by raising costs for app devs and customers, while also acting as a barrier to entering a free market.

Apple denied any wrongdoing, claiming it isn’t the dominant player in India and has an insignificant (around 0 to 5 percent) market share, whereas Google’s Android dominated with a 90 to 100 percent market share. Post this, the body launched a probe for investigation.

As per the report, the investigation will now look at each of the three separate cases that have been filed against Apple.
